Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Situation2: They interact warmly with a long line of shoppers during a busy lunch hour.
Story: I glanced at the clock above my register, my fingers moving automatically as I scanned groceries and smiled at the next customer. The lunch rush was in full swing, and the line stretched down the aisle. My manager had reminded us to be extra friendly today—corporate was watching, and every customer’s experience mattered. I forced a cheerful tone, even as my phone buzzed in my apron pocket for the third time. I knew it was my sister, probably asking when I’d be home. Tonight was Mom’s birthday, and everyone expected me to be there for the family dinner. I could almost hear my dad’s voice: “We’re all counting on you to make it special.” But the line wasn’t getting any shorter, and my shift wasn’t over for another hour. I felt the pressure building—my family needed me, but so did my customers and my boss. My heart pounded as I handed back change, caught between the warmth of home and the demands of my job, not sure which role I was about to let down.
